newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ govt concerned by petrol, diesel import margins.
newsitem.headline: NZ govt concerned by petrol, diesel import margins.

text.p: Energy Minister Max Bradford on Tuesday said he was concerned about rising petrol and diesel importer margins and wanted to encourage competition in the sector.
"There is some evidence of rising petrol and diesel importer margins which is of concern to the government.

"I am keen to see more vigorous competition in the New Zealand petrol and diesel markets than there perhaps is now. This competition should extend to price and not just service," Bradford told the launch of the private sector energy umbrella group, the Energy Federation.
Bradford said rising margins were likely to encourage new entry into petrol retailing.

"I would like to see supermarket chains and the proposed new supermalls take up the challenge of retailing petrol," Bradford said, adding that this would put pressure on prices and wholesaler margins.

"I intend to ensure any barriers which may prevent the emergence of competitive retailing by supermarkets are removed." Bradford said he had a prefence, but not a dogmatic one, for light-handed regulation to address issues of market power and natural monopoly.
"Information disclosure in particular should, but is not guaranteed to, allow industry players to monitor each other and facilitiate the use of general competition law against each other."
He said domestic electricity consumers had not yet seen the benefits of reform, and he expected the industry to take "a good hard look" at its domestic contracts.
Industry disclosure requirements would be tightened this year to separate and ring-fence the natural monopoly components from contestible activities.
"Line businesses will have to operate in a goldfish bowl where their activities, charging systems and contracts are more transparent than at present," Bradford said.
He said the government was reviewing progress on pricing the Cook Strait cable "and may be faced with having to take further steps to resolve the current inmpasse soon."
He said New Zealand should not penalise itself by getting ahead of its trading partners in adopting environmental hurdles which would place an extra cost on industry.
